To this petition there was filed an exception of no cause of action and subsequently the answer which substantially claims, admitting the accident, that the bruises received were not such calculated to do greet bodily harm or cause serious injury; that plaintiff was not so seriously injured that it would him to cause/kiisxksxa lose his position as fireman or in any wise affect him personan, save and except that possibly the scars on his neck might remain for a while and then become as other parts of *753his body, also claiming that plaintiff was intoxioated and that the glass was cracked, but otherwise there was no serious injury.

It has oewtassiaC¡jac¡ic been established beyond doubt that the allegations of plaintiff's petition, through his testimony and that of his sister-in-law and other members of his family, together with his physician, that the injuries caused by the accident as above stated oould have been avoided by the defendant's employee by oareful driving; that it was at the time of the evening, just before six o'clock, when the stump in the rosd oould have been seen and should have been skhí seen, bút recklessly and carelessly as we think, and this testimony justifies us in this opinion, this chauffeur drove plaintiff in a manner to cause the injuries claimed by him and whilst we believe do not /oonsBaxaec that possibly they were serious, as serious as to oause injury for life, yet they were amply illustrated by plaintiff's appearance in several months after this trial in the Court aquo when he still gs.ve evidence of what his testimony has proven.

There is no justification whatever on the part of the defendant company nor do we believe that plaintiff was drunk or in any wise affected on this particular oooassion; he denies it end so do members of his family and the only witness who pretends to anything of this sort in is the chauffeur himself.

The Civil Code provides, Art. 3315."Every aot whatever of man that causes damage to another, obligates him by 'whose fault it happens to repair it. "

A oareful examination of this record convinces us that plaintiff has told the plain, unvarnished truth of the unfortuante accident and the injuries that he received; his testimony is complete, full and to our minds entirely satisfactory; besides this he was before the District Judge who saw and heard him, together with the witnesses on both sides of the case end under the circumstances his opinion in this *754matter, being entirely a question of fact, having the witnesses before him, seeing them, hearing them testify, has been held ever to be an important faotor in the decision of oases,

. ' - and under these circumstances, appreciating these facts and that his Honor the Judge of the Lower Court heard and saw the witnesses and rendered an opinion in this case which in our opinion does justice to the parties, we wee no reason to disturb it.
